CDISC Definition: A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the activity.
The textual representation of the study activity.
The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) of the clinical study activity.
The explanation for why the study activity is subject to or dependent upon something else.
An indication as to whether the study activity is subject to or dependent upon something else.
The explanation for why the study activity is available to be performed but is not obligatory.
An indication as to whether the study activity is available to be performed but is not obligatory.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the address.
A standardized representation of the complete set of components denoting the physical address of the person, business, building, or organization.
The street name and number, building number, apartment or unit number, or post office box number where an entity is physically located.
A relatively large and/or densely populated area of human habitation with administrative or legal status that may be specified as a component of a postal address.
A sovereign nation occupying a distinct territory and ruled by an autonomous government.
An administrative or territorial division of a city, town, county, parish, state, country, or other locality based on a shared characteristic.
An alphanumeric code assigned to a mail delivery area.
A sub-division of a country that forms part of a federal union. States are usually, but not always, more autonomous than provinces and may have different laws from the central government.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the analysis population.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Analysis Population Attribute Terminology

CDISC Submission Value: Target Study Population for Analysis Description
CDISC Definition: The textual representation of the study population for analysis.
NCI Preferred Term: Target Study Population for Analysis Description

CDISC Definition: A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the biomedical concept.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Biomedical Concept Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) of the biomedical concept.
A citation to an authoritative source for a biomedical concept.
A word or an expression that serves as a figurative, symbolic, or exact substitute for a biomedical concept, and which has the same meaning.

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Category Attribute Terminology
CDISC Submission Value: DDF Biomedical Concept Category Attribute Terminology
CDISC Synonym(s): DDF Biomedical Concept Category Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the biomedical concept category.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Biomedical Concept Category Attribute Terminology

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Category Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the biomedical concept category.

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Category Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: The textual representation of the biomedical concept category.

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Category Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) of the biomedical concept category.

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Property Attribute Terminology
CDISC Submission Value: DDF Biomedical Concept Property Attribute Terminology
CDISC Synonym(s): DDF Biomedical Concept Property Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the biomedical concept property.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Biomedical Concept Property Attribute Terminology

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Property Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A concept unique identifier assigned to a biomedical concept property that points to the meaning of that biomedical concept property.

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Property Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: An indication as to whether the biomedical concept property is activated for use within a given usage context for a biomedical concept.

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Property Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) of the biomedical concept property.

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Property Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: An indication as to whether the biomedical concept property is required.

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Property Attribute Terminology
CDISC Submission Value: Biomedical Concept Property Response Data Type
CDISC Definition: The structural format of the biomedical concept property response value. The datatype is carried in the attribute and influences the set of allowable values the attribute may assume. (After HL7)
NCI Preferred Term: Biomedical Concept Property Response Data Type

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Surrogate Attribute Terminology
CDISC Submission Value: DDF Biomedical Concept Surrogate Attribute Terminology
CDISC Synonym(s): DDF Biomedical Concept Surrogate Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the biomedical concept surrogate.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Biomedical Concept Surrogate Attribute Terminology

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Surrogate Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: The textual representation of the biomedical concept surrogate.

Codelist Name: DDF Biomedical Concept Surrogate Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A citation to an authoritative source for a biomedical concept surrogate.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the clinical study.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Clinical Study Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: A therapeutic area classification based on the structure and operations of the business unit.
A word or words formed from the beginning letters or a combination of syllables and letters of a compound term, which identifies a clinical study.

A statement describing the overall rationale of the study. This field describes the contribution of this study to product development, i.e., what knowledge is being contributed from the conduct of this study.

CDISC Synonym(s): Official Study Title; Study Title; Trial Title
CDISC Definition: The sponsor-defined name of the clinical study.
The nature of the investigation for which study information is being collected. (After clinicaltrials.gov)
A plan at a particular point in time for a study.

A step in the clinical research and development of a therapy from initial clinical trials to post-approval studies. NOTE: Clinical trials are generally categorized into four (sometimes five) phases. A therapeutic intervention may be evaluated in two or more phases simultaneously in different trials, and some trials may overlap two different phases. [21 CFR section 312.21; After ICH Topic E8 NOTE FOR GUIDANCE ON GENERAL CONSIDERATIONS FOR CLINICAL TRIALS, CPMP/ICH/291/95 March 1998]
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the code.
The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) of the system used to assign and/or manage codes.
The version of the code system.
The literal value of a code.
Standardized or dictionary-derived human readable text associated with a code.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the encounter.
The textual representation of the protocol-defined clinical encounter.
The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) for a protocol-defined clinical encounter.
A characterization or classification of contact between subject/patient and healthcare practitioner/researcher, during which an assessment or activity is performed.
The means by which an interaction occurs between the subject/participant and person or entity (e.g., a device).
The environment/setting where the event, intervention, or finding occurred.
A system identifier assigned to a clinical encounter that occurs immediately after the current clinical encounter.
A system identifier assigned to a clinical encounter that occurs immediately prior to the current clinical encounter.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the endpoint.
The textual representation of the study endpoint.
A characterization or classification of the study endpoint that determines its category of importance relative to other study endpoints.
The textual representation of the study endpoint purpose.
A terminology value set relevant to the entities within the CDISC digital data flow (DDF) model.
A standardized representation of the location of a person, business, building, or organization. (NCI)
An alternative symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
A grouping of biomedical concepts based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
A characteristic from a set of characteristics used to define a biomedical concept.

A unit of biomedical knowledge created from a unique combination of characteristics that include implementation details like variables and terminologies, used as building blocks for standardized, hierarchically structured clinical research information.
Contact between subject/patient and healthcare practitioner/researcher, during which an assessment or activity is performed. Contact may be physical or virtual.

A clinical study involves research using human volunteers (also called participants) that is intended to add to medical knowledge. There are two main types of clinical studies: clinical trials (also called interventional studies) and observational studies. [ClinicalTrials.gov] See also clinical trial. (CDISC Glossary)
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
A health problem or disease that is identified as likely to be benefited by a therapy being studied in clinical trials.

A precise description of the treatment effect reflecting the clinical question posed by a given clinical trial objective. It summarises at a population level what the outcomes would be in the same patients under different treatment conditions being compared. (ICH E9 R1 Addendum)

CDISC Synonym(s): Investigational Interventional; Investigational Therapy or Treatment
CDISC Definition: The drug, device, therapy, or process under investigation in a clinical study that is believed to have an effect on outcomes of interest in a study (e.g., health-related quality of life, efficacy, safety, pharmacoeconomics). [After https://grants.nih.gov/grants/policy/faq_clinical_trial_definition.htm#5224]

An event(s) occurring after treatment initiation that affects either the interpretation or the existence of the measurements associated with the clinical question of interest. (ICH E9 Addendum on Estimands)
A formalized group of persons or other organizations collected together for a common purpose (such as administrative, legal, political) and the infrastructure to carry out that purpose. (BRIDG)
Any activity performed by manual and/or instrumental means for the purpose of diagnosis, assessment, therapy, prevention, or palliative care.
A symbol or combination of symbols representing the response to the question.
To go out of or leave the schedule timeline.
A chronological schedule of planned temporal events.
A scheduled occurrence of an activity event.
A scheduled occurrence of a decision event.
A scheduled occurrence of a temporal event.
An action, undertaking, or event, which is anticipated to be performed or observed, or was performed or observed, according to the study protocol during the execution of the study.
A planned pathway assigned to the subject as they progress through the study, usually referred to by a name that reflects one or more treatments, exposures, and/or controls included in the path.
A partitioning of a study arm into individual pieces, which are associated with an epoch and any number of sequential elements within that epoch.

A basic building block for time within a clinical study comprising the following characteristics: a description of what happens to the subject during the element; a definition of the start of the element; a rule for ending the element.
A plan detailing how a study will be performed in order to represent the phenomenon under examination, to answer the research questions that have been asked, and informing the statistical approach.

A defined variable intended to reflect an outcome of interest that is statistically analyzed to address a particular research question. NOTE: A precise definition of an endpoint typically specifies the type of assessments made, the timing of those assessments, the assessment tools used, and possibly other details, as applicable, such as how multiple assessments within an individual are to be combined. [After BEST Resource] (CDISC Glossary)
A named time period defined in the protocol, wherein a study activity is specified and unchanging throughout the interval, to support a study-specific purpose.
A sequence of characters used to identify, name, or characterize the study.
The reason for performing a study in terms of the scientific questions to be answered by the analysis of data collected during the study.

A plan at a particular point in time for a formal investigation to assess the utility, impact, pharmacological, physiological, and/or psychological effects of a particular treatment, procedure, drug, device, biologic, food product, cosmetic, care plan, or subject characteristic. (BRIDG)

A target study population on which an analysis is performed. These may be represented by the entire study population, a subgroup defined by a particular characteristic measured at baseline, or a principal stratum defined by the occurrence (or non-occurrence, depending on context) of a specific intercurrent event. (ICH E9 R1 Addendum)
The population within the general population for which the study results can be generalized.
The chronological relationship between temporal events.
A guide that governs the allocation of subjects to operational options at a discrete decision point or branch (e.g., assignment to a particular arm, discontinuation) within a clinical trial plan.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the estimand.
A synopsis of the clinical endpoint of interest within the analysis target study population.
The variable identified as the focus for developing the estimand.
NCI Preferred Term: Variable of Interest for the Estimand

CDISC Definition: A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the disease indication.
A short sequence of characters that represents the disease indication.

CDISC Synonym(s): Indication for Use; Trial Disease/Condition Indication; Trial Disease/Condition Indication Description
CDISC Definition: The textual representation of the condition, disease or disorder that the clinical trial is intended to investigate or address.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the intercurrent event.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Intercurrent Event Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: The textual representation of the intercurrent event.
The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) of the intercurrent event.
A textual description of the planned strategy to manage and/or mitigate intercurrent events.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the investigational interventions.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Investigational Interventions Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: The textual representation of the study intervention.
A short sequence of characters that represents the investigational intervention.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the objective.
The textual representation of the study objective. (BRIDG)
A characterization or classification of the study objective that determines its category of importance relative to other study objectives.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the organization.
The name of the organization that provides the identifier for the entity.
A unique symbol that establishes identity of the organization. (BRIDG)
A non-unique textual identifier for the organization. (BRIDG)

A characterization or classification of the formalized group of persons or other organizations collected together for a common purpose (such as administrative, legal, political) and the infrastructure to carry out that purpose.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the procedure.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to medical procedure.
The textual representation of the procedure.
The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) of the procedure.
A characterization or classification of the study procedure.
The explanation for why the study procedure is subject to or dependent upon something else.
An indication as to whether the study procedure is subject to or dependent upon something else.
The explanation for why the study procedure is available to be performed but is not obligatory.
An indication as to whether the study procedure is available to be performed but is not obligatory.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the response code.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Response Code Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
An indication as to whether the response code is activated for use within a given usage context.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the schedule timeline.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Schedule Timeline Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: An indication as to whether the timeline or timeline component is part of the central or principal timeline.
The textual representation of the schedule timeline.
A logical evaluation on which rests the validity of entry into a schedule timeline.
The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) of the schedule timeline.

Codelist Name: DDF Scheduled Decision Instance Attribute Terminology
CDISC Submission Value: DDF Scheduled Decision Instance Attribute Terminology
CDISC Synonym(s): DDF Scheduled Decision Instance Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the scheduled decision instance.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Scheduled Decision Instance Attribute Terminology

Codelist Name: DDF Scheduled Decision Instance Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: An allotting or appointment to a set of conditions that are to be met in order to make a logical decision.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the scheduled instance.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Scheduled Instance Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: A numeral or string of numerals expressing a relative sequence of scheduled temporal events.
A characterization or classification of the scheduled instance.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the study Arm.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Study Arm Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: The textual representation of the study arm data origin.
A characterization or classification of the study arm with respect to where the study arm data originates.
The textual representation of the arm for the study.
The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) of the study arm.
A characterization or classification of the study arm.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the study design.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Study Design Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: The general design of the strategy for assigning interventions to participants in a clinical study. (clinicaltrials.gov)

CDISC Synonym(s): Overall Design; Study Design Description; Study Design Overview; Summary of Study Design
CDISC Definition: Summary description of the overall study plan and design, should include treatments studied, population studied, level and method of blinding/unmasking, kind of controls, method of assignment to treatment, sequence and duration of study periods, any safety, data monitoring or special steering or evaluation committees, and interim analyses. (ICH E3)
The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) of the study design.
Reason(s) for choosing the study design. This may include reasons for the choice of control or comparator, as well as the scientific rationale for the study design.

A categorization of a disease, disorder, or other condition based on common characteristics and often associated with a medical specialty focusing on research and development of specific therapeutic interventions for the purpose of treatment and prevention.

CDISC Synonym(s): Study Blinding Design; Study Blinding Schema; Study Masking Design; Trial Blinding Design; Trial Blinding Schema; Trial Masking Design
CDISC Definition: The type of experimental design used to describe the level of awareness of the study subjects and/ or study personnel as it relates to the respective intervention(s) or assessments being observed, received or administered.
The planned purpose of the therapy, device, or agent under study in the clinical trial.
The nature of the interventional study for which information is being collected.

Codelist Name: DDF Study Design Population Attribute Terminology
CDISC Submission Value: DDF Study Design Population Attribute Terminology
CDISC Synonym(s): DDF Study Design Population Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the study design population.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Study Design Population Attribute Terminology

Codelist Name: DDF Study Design Population Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: The anticipated maximum age of the subjects to be entered in a clinical trial. (NCI)

Codelist Name: DDF Study Design Population Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: The anticipated minimum age of the subjects to be entered in a clinical trial. (NCI)

Codelist Name: DDF Study Design Population Attribute Terminology
CDISC Synonym(s): Anticipated Enrollment; Planned Enrollment; Planned Number of Subjects; Target Enrollment
CDISC Definition: The planned number of subjects to be entered in a clinical trial. (NCI)

Codelist Name: DDF Study Design Population Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: The specific sex, either male, female, or mixed of the subject group being studied. (NCI)

Codelist Name: DDF Study Design Population Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: The textual representation of the study population.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the study element.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Study Element Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: The textual representation of the study design element.
The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) of the study design element.
A criterion that establishes the end of a subject transition within a study workflow.
A criterion that establishes the beginning of a subject transition within a study workflow.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the study epoch.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Study Epoch Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: A system identifier assigned to the epoch that occurs immediately after the current epoch.
A system identifier assigned to the epoch that occurs immediately prior to the current epoch.
The textual representation of the study epoch.

The literal identifier (i.e., distinctive designation) of the study epoch, i.e., the named time period defined in the protocol, wherein a study activity is specified and unchanging throughout the interval, to support a study-specific purpose.

A characterization or classification of the study epoch, i.e., the named time period defined in the protocol, wherein a study activity is specified and unchanging throughout the interval, to support a study-specific purpose.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the study identifier.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Study Identifier Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: A sequence of characters used to identify, name, or characterize the study.

Codelist Name: DDF Study Protocol Version Attribute Terminology
CDISC Submission Value: DDF Study Protocol Version Attribute Terminology
CDISC Synonym(s): DDF Study Protocol Version Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the study protocol version.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Study Protocol Version Attribute Terminology

Codelist Name: DDF Study Protocol Version Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: The short descriptive name for the protocol.

Codelist Name: DDF Study Protocol Version Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: The formal descriptive name for the protocol.

Codelist Name: DDF Study Protocol Version Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A condition of the protocol at a point in time with respect to its state of readiness for implementation.

Codelist Name: DDF Study Protocol Version Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: The descriptive name of the protocol that is intended for the lay public, written in easily understood language.
NCI Preferred Term: Study Protocol Document Version Public Title

Codelist Name: DDF Study Protocol Version Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A more extensive descriptive name of the protocol that is intended for medical professionals, written using medical and scientific language.

Codelist Name: DDF Study Protocol Version Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: The date and time specifying when the protocol amendment takes effect or becomes operative.

Codelist Name: DDF Study Protocol Version Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A written description of a change(s) to, or formal clarification of, a protocol. (ICH E6)

Codelist Name: DDF Study Protocol Version Attribute Terminology
CDISC Definition: A plan at a particular point in time for a formal investigation to assess the utility, impact, pharmacological, physiological, and/or psychological effects of a particular treatment, procedure, drug, device, biologic, food product, cosmetic, care plan, or subject characteristic. (BRIDG)
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the timing.
The textual representation of the chronological relationship between temporal events.
The name of the reference event used to define the temporal relationship with another event.
A characterization or classification of the chronological relationship between temporal events.
The temporal value of the chronological relationship between temporal events.
A time period, or other type of interval, during which a temporal event may be achieved, obtained, or observed.
The earliest chronological value of an allowable period of time during which a temporal event takes place.
The latest chronological value of an allowable period of time during which a temporal event takes place.
A terminology value set relevant to the attributes of the transition rule.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Transition Rule Attribute Terminology

CDISC Definition: The textual representation of the transition rule.
The terminology relevant to the encounter type.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Encounter Type Value Set Terminology

CDISC Definition: The act of going to see some person or place or thing; it can cover a short or long period but refers to a non-permanent arrangement.
The terminology relevant to the endpoint level.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Endpoint Level Value Set Terminology

CDISC Definition: Endpoint(s) that may include clinically important events that are expected to occur too infrequently to show a treatment effect or endpoints that for other reasons are thought to be less likely to show an effect but are included to explore new hypotheses. (After FDA-NIH Protocol Template)

Endpoint(s) of greatest importance that is the basis for concluding whether the study met its objective(s) and provides a clinically relevant, valid, and reliable measure of the primary objective(s). (After FDA-NIH Protocol Template)

Endpoint(s) that may provide supportive information about the effect of the study intervention(s) on the primary endpoint or demonstrate additional effects on the disease or condition. (After FDA-NIH Protocol Template)
Terminology relevant to the surroundings or environment.
An establishment that provides care for infants and children.
A health care facility where subjects or patients may receive assessments, procedures, or treatments that are provided by physicians and other healthcare providers.
A tract of land cultivated for the purpose of agricultural production or devoted to the raising and breeding of domestic animals.
A setting outside the clinic or a comparable health care facility, e.g. a doctor's office, the subject's home or workplace, a school, a public park, or a restaurant.
The buildings and organizations where healthcare services are provided.
A person's place of residence.
An institution that provides medical, surgical, or psychiatric care and treatment for the sick or the injured.
The area in which an individual lives.

An established society, corporation, foundation or other organization founded and united for a specific purpose, e.g. for health-related research; also used to refer to a building or buildings occupied or used by such organization.
A motorized conveyance for people and goods.
An area outside of that in which an individual lives.
Any environmental setting outside of a clinic.
A medical care center that provides healthcare services on an outpatient basis.
An institution where persons are confined for punishment and to protect the public.
An educational institution.
Temporary housing for displaced or at-risk persons.
The surroundings or environment in which social activities occur.
Place or physical location of work or employment.
The name of the EPOCH.
A period in a clinical study after eligibility has been met and before the start of treatment, at which baseline measurements are collected.
A period in a clinical study during which subjects receive blinded therapeutic treatment.
A period in a clinical study during which subjects receive continuation treatment.
A period in a clinical study during which information about the health status of an individual is obtained after study interventions have concluded.
A period in a clinical study during which subjects receive induction treatment.
A period in a clinical study during which information about the health status of an individual is obtained long after study interventions have concluded.
A period in a clinical study during which subjects are observed, without any planned intervention.
A period in a clinical study during which subjects receive open label therapeutic treatment.
A period in a clinical study during which subjects are evaluated prior to entering the full screening period.

A period in a clinical study that occurs after screening and before randomization, during which the subject is further evaluated and/or prepared for the commencement of the clinical study investigation.
A period in a clinical study during which subjects are evaluated for participation in the study.
A period in a study during which subjects are receiving investigational therapy or treatment.
A period of time during a study when a subject is taken off of the investigational therapy or treatment in order to reduce the amount of investigational product within the body.
A terminology codelist relevant to the trial design developed to compare treatment groups.
Participants receive one of two or more alternative intervention(s) during the initial epoch of the study and receive other intervention(s) during the subsequent epoch(s) of the study.

Two or more interventions, each alone or in combination, are evaluated in parallel against a control group. This study design allows for the comparison of active drug to placebo, presence of drug-drug interactions, and comparison of active drugs against each other.
Participants are assigned to one of two or more treatment groups in parallel for the duration of the study.
Groups of participants are assigned to receive interventions based on prior milestones being reached in the study. (clinicaltrials.gov)
All trial participants are assigned to a single treatment group for the duration of the study.
Terminology relevant to the means by which interaction occurs between the subject and person or entity.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC SDTM Mode of Subject Contact Terminology

CDISC Definition: Composing, sending, and receiving messages over electronic communication systems.
An interaction that takes place in the physical presence of someone else.

A type of automated system in which individuals can access information menus containing pre-recorded or dynamically generated information with voice prompts, without the need for an agent or operator.
A written message addressed to a person or organization.
A form of remote communication by audio video technology.
A form of remote communication by audio technology.
Receipt of shipped material was confirmed by signature.
Communication by way of telephone.
A short electronic communication, usually sent and received by a mobile phone.
The terminology relevant to the objective level.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Objective Level Value Set Terminology

CDISC Synonym(s): Study Primary Objective; Trial Primary Objective
CDISC Definition: A principle objective of the study.

CDISC Synonym(s): Study Secondary Objective; Trial Secondary Objective
CDISC Definition: An auxiliary objective of the study.
The terminology relevant to the organization type.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Organization Type Value Set Terminology

CDISC Definition: An organization (typically a government agency) that administers the registration of studies. (BRIDG)

CDISC Synonym(s): Clinical Study Sponsor; Sponsor; Study Sponsor
CDISC Definition: An individual, company, institution, or organization that takes responsibility for the initiation, management, and/or financing of a clinical study. [After ICH E6, WHO, 21 CFR 50.3 (e), and after IDMP]

An organization (typically a government agency) that is responsible for implementing and enforcing laws, licensing and regulating products and services, promoting the use of standards, and ensuring safety and consumer protections.
The terminology relevant to the protocol status.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Protocol Status Value Set Terminology

CDISC Definition: Acceptance as satisfactory by an authoritative body; established by authority; given authoritative approval.
A preliminary version of a written work, design, or picture.
Conclusive in a process or progression.
No longer in use or valid; old.
A preliminary version of a written work, design, or picture that is awaiting review.
A terminology codelist relevant to the specific sex, either male, female, or mixed of the subject group being studied.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC SDTM Sex of Study Group Terminology

CDISC Definition: One and the other; relating to or being two in conjunction. (NCI)
A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces ova. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, or cultural gender role distinctions, or both. (NCI)
A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both. (NCI)

Codelist Name: Study Arm Data Origin Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Submission Value: Study Arm Data Origin Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Synonym(s): Study Arm Data Origin Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: The terminology relevant to the study arm data origin type.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Study Arm Data Origin Type Value Set Terminology

Codelist Name: Study Arm Data Origin Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: Data that are generated from the current study.

Codelist Name: Study Arm Data Origin Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: Data from studies that have occurred in the past.

Codelist Name: Study Arm Data Origin Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: Data relating to patient health status and/or the delivery of health care routinely collected from sources other than traditional clinical trials. NOTE: Examples of sources include data derived from electronic health records (EHRs); medical claims and billing data; data from product and disease registries; patient-generated data, including from in-home-use settings; and data gathered from other sources that can inform on health status, such as mobile devices. [After 21 U.S.C. 355g(b)).5 and Framework for FDA's Real-World Evidence Program December 2018] See also Real-World Evidence (RWE)

Codelist Name: Study Arm Data Origin Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: Data that are artificially created rather than being generated by actual events. NOTE: Data are often created with the help of algorithms and used for a wide range of activities, including as test data for new products and tools, for model validation, and in AI optimization. [After The Ultimate Guide to Synthetic Data in 2020, August 29, 2020]. See also artificial intelligence.

Codelist Name: Study Arm Data Origin Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: Data that are generated from virtual encounters between investigators and subjects.

Codelist Name: Study Arm Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Submission Value: Study Arm Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Synonym(s): Study Arm Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: The terminology relevant to the identification of the kind of arm.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC Protocol Study Arm Type Value Set Terminology

Codelist Name: Study Arm Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: An arm describing the active comparator.

Codelist Name: Study Arm Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: An arm describing the intervention or treatment plan for a group of participants in the study receiving a control. The control may comprise a non-investigational product (active control) or regimen, placebo, or no treatment.

Codelist Name: Study Arm Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: An arm describing the intervention or treatment plan for a group of participants in the study receiving test product(s).

Codelist Name: Study Arm Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: A study arm without an intervention or treatment.

Codelist Name: Study Arm Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: An arm describing the placebo comparator.

Codelist Name: Study Arm Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: An arm describing the sham comparator.

Codelist Name: Study Arm Type Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: An arm describing the intervention or treatment plan for a group of participants in the study. Treatment may consist of either experimental or control products under investigation.
A terminology codelist relevant to the role the study plays in determining the interventions a subject receives.

Studies that provide a means for obtaining an experimental drug or device for patients who are not adequately treated by existing therapy, who do not meet the eligibility criteria for enrollment, or who are otherwise unable to participate in another clinical study.

Studies in which individuals are assigned by an investigator based on a protocol to receive specific interventions. Subjects may receive diagnostic, therapeutic or other types of interventions. The assignment of the intervention may or may not be random. The individuals are then followed and biomedical and/or health outcomes are assessed.

Studies in which biomedical and/or health outcomes are assessed in pre-defined groups of individuals. Subjects in the study may receive diagnostic, therapeutic, or other interventions, but the investigator does not assign specific interventions to the subjects of the study.

Observational studies which include an organized system that uses observational methods to collect uniform data (clinical and other) prospectively for a population defined by a particular disorder/disease, condition (including susceptibility to a disorder), or exposure (including products, health care services, and/or procedures) and that serves a predetermined scientific, clinical, or policy purpose. Patient registries may be single purpose or on-going data collection programs that address one or more questions. (AHRQ)

Codelist Name: Timing Relative To From Value Set Terminology
CDISC Submission Value: Timing Relative To From Value Set Terminology
CDISC Synonym(s): Timing Relative To From Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: The terminology relevant to the timing relative to from value set.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Timing Relative To From Value Set Terminology

Codelist Name: Timing Relative To From Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: A timing relationship defined as the end of one event to the end of another event.

Codelist Name: Timing Relative To From Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: A timing relationship defined as the end of one event to the start of another event.

Codelist Name: Timing Relative To From Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: A timing relationship defined as the start of one event to the end of another event.

Codelist Name: Timing Relative To From Value Set Terminology
CDISC Definition: A timing relationship defined as the start of one event to the start of another event.
The terminology relevant to the timing type value set.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC DDF Timing Type Value Set Terminology

CDISC Definition: A type of time point relationship that follows a point or period of time within a timeline.
A type of time point relationship that comes before a point or period of time within a timeline.
A type of time point relationship that is fixed with respect to a timeline.
A terminology codelist relevant to the type of blinding for the trial.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC SDTM Trial Blinding Schema Terminology

CDISC Definition: A study in which neither the subject nor the study personnel interacting with the subject or data during the study knows what intervention a subject is receiving.

A study in which the study personnel who measure, record, or assess the subject do not know which intervention the subject is receiving or, in the context of observational studies, do not know the external factors to which a subject has been exposed.

CDISC Submission Value: OPEN LABEL TO TREATMENT AND DOUBLE BLIND TO IMP DOSE
CDISC Definition: A study in which the therapeutic treatment is open label but the dosing information of the investigational medicinal product (IMP) is double-blinded.
NCI Preferred Term: Open Label for Treatment And Double Blind to Dose

CDISC Definition: A study in which subjects and study personnel know which intervention each subject is receiving.
A study in which one party, either the subject or study personnel, does not know which intervention is administered to the subject.
A terminology codelist relevant to the responses for the planned purpose of the therapy, device, or agent under study in the clinical trial.
NCI Preferred Term: CDISC SDTM Trial Indication Type Terminology

CDISC Definition: A type of study designed to examine the basic mechanism of action (e.g., physiology, biomechanics) of an intervention. (ClinicalTrials.gov)
A type of study designed to evaluate intervention(s) aimed to cure a disease or condition.

An intervention of a device product is being evaluated to determine the feasibility of the product or to test a prototype device and not health outcomes. Such studies are conducted to confirm the design and operating specifications of a device before beginning a full clinical trial. (ClinicalTrials.gov)
A type of study designed to evaluate intervention(s) aimed at identifying a disease or condition.
A type of study designed to evaluate the effects of treatment(s) intended to cause a change in disease, syndrome, or condition beyond the point of treatment administration.
A type of study designed to evaluate the delivery, processes, management, organization or financing of health care. (ClinicalTrials.gov)
A type of study designed to identify actions necessary to eliminate or reduce the risk to human life or well-being as a result of a particular medication or treatment regimen. (NCI)
A type of study designed to identify actions necessary to permanently eliminate or reduce the long-term risk to human life as a result of a particular medication or treatment regimen.

A type of study designed to assess or examine methods of identifying a condition (or risk factors for a condition) in people who are not yet known to have the condition (or risk factor). (Clinicaltrials.gov)

A type of study designed to evaluate one or more interventions where the primary intent is to maximize comfort, minimize side effects or mitigate against a decline in the subject's health or function. In general, supportive care interventions are not intended to cure a disease. (ClinicalTrials.gov)
A type of study designed to evaluate intervention(s) for treatment of disease, syndrome or condition.
A terminology codelist relevant to the phase, or stage, of the clinical trial.
Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context. (NCI)

First-in-human trials, in a small number of subjects, that are conducted before Phase 1 trials and are intended to assess new candidate therapeutic and imaging agents. The study agent is administered at a low dose for a limited time, and there is no therapeutic or diagnostic intent. NOTE: FDA Guidance for Industry, Investigators, and Reviewers: Exploratory IND Studies, January 2006 classifies such studies as Phase 1. NOTE: A Phase 0 study might not include any drug delivery but may be an exploration of human material from a study (e.g., tissue samples or biomarker determinations). [Improving the Quality of Cancer Clinical Trials: Workshop summary-Proceedings of the National Cancer Policy Forum Workshop, improving the Quality of Cancer Clinical Trials (Washington, DC, Oct 2007)] (CDISC glossary)

The initial introduction of an investigational new drug into humans. Phase 1 studies are typically closely monitored and may be conducted in patients or normal volunteer subjects. NOTE: These studies are designed to determine the metabolism and pharmacologic actions of the drug in humans, the side effects associated with increasing doses, and, if possible, to gain early evidence on effectiveness. During Phase 1, sufficient information about the drug's pharmacokinetics and pharmacological effects should be obtained to permit the design of well-controlled, scientifically valid, Phase 2 studies. The total number of subjects and patients included in Phase I studies varies with the drug, but is generally in the range of 20 to 80. Phase 1 studies also include studies of drug metabolism, structure-activity relationships, and mechanism of action in humans, as well as studies in which investigational drugs are used as research tools to explore biological phenomena or disease processes. [After FDA CDER Handbook, ICH E8] (CDISC glossary)
A class of clinical study that combines elements characteristic of traditional Phase I and Phase II trials. See also Phase I, Phase II.
A study that begins as a Phase I study and transitions into Phases II and III based upon successful completion of each previous portion.
A study that begins as a Phase I study and transitions into a Phase III study upon successful completion of the Phase I portion.
A type of phase 1 trial with a single ascending dose (dose escalation) in a smaller group of patients (in comparison to a Phase 1B).
A type of phase 1 trial with multiple ascending doses (dose expansion) in a larger group of patients (in comparison to a Phase 1A).

Phase that includes the controlled clinical trials conducted to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the drug in a limited number of patients with the disease or condition under study. Objectives can be dose-ranging (dose-response, frequency of dosing), type of patients, or numerous other characteristics of safety and efficacy. [After 21 CRF Part 312.21 Phases of an investigation] See also phase, phase 2a, phase 2b. (CDISC Glossary)
A class of clinical study that combines elements characteristic of traditional Phase II and Phase III trials.

Early Phase 2 trials that focus on a proof-of-concept assessment of efficacy and safety in a small number of patients. [After FDA Guidance for industry end of Phase 2a meetings, September 2009] (CDISC Glossary)

Later Phase 2 trials, in transition to Phase 3, where the study populations more closely reflect the population, dosage, and condition for intended use. [Clarification of FDA Guidance for industry end of Phase 2a meetings, September 2009; Discussion in Peter B. Gilbert. SOME DESIGN ISSUES IN PHASE 2B VERSUS PHASE 3 PREVENTION TRIALS FOR TESTING EFFICACY OF PRODUCTS OR CONCEPTS. Stat Med. 2010 May 10; 29(10): 1061-1071.]

Phase that includes the controlled clinical trials intended to confirm safety and effectiveness, evaluate the overall benefit-risk relationship, and to provide substantial evidence for regulatory approval and labeling. NOTE: Phase 3 studies usually include from several hundred to several thousand subjects. [After ICH E8; Demonstrating Substantial Evidence of Effectiveness for Human Drug and Biological Products Draft Guidance for Industry. December 2019] See also phase, phase 3b. (CDISC Glossary)
A classification typically assigned retrospectively to a Phase III trial upon determination by regulatory authorities of a need for a Phase III B trial. (NCI)

Later Phase 3 trial done near the time of approval to elicit additional findings. NOTE: Dossier review may continue while associated Phase 3b trials are conducted. These trials may be required as a condition of regulatory authority approval. Phase 3a is in common usage but not reflected in regulatory guidance. (CDISC Glossary)

Post-approval studies to delineate additional information about the drug's risks, benefits, and optimal use that may be requested by regulatory authorities in conjunction with marketing approval. NOTE: Phase 4 studies could include, but would not be limited to, studying different doses or schedules of administration than were used in Phase 2 studies, use of the drug in other patient populations or other stages of the disease, or use of the drug over a longer period of time. [after FDA CDER handbook, ICH E8] See also phase. (CDISC Glossary)
Postmarketing surveillance is sometimes referred to as Phase V.
A terminology codelist relevant to the type of primary outcome or endpoint that the protocol is designed to evaluate.
A type of study designed to evaluate the strength of the bond between an adhesive and the application surface.
A type of study designed to evaluate the effects of alcohol on investigational product safety and/or efficacy.
A study of the degree to which or rate at which a drug or other substance is absorbed or becomes available at the site of physiological activity after administration. (NCI)

A study most often used to compare the efficacy of different formulations to treat a given disease. It is the testing of an old versus a new formulation in healthy volunteers or subjects with the disease under study and usually in one dose. (NCI)
A type of study designed to evaluate whether a biologic test article is highly similar in function and effect to an existing biologic that has already been clinically tested and approved for use.
A type of study designed to evaluate the interaction between a device and a drug, where the use of one may affect the disposition, function, efficacy, or safety of the other.
A type of study designed to evaluate intervention(s) aimed at identifying a disease or condition.
An early phase clinical study with the objective of determining the optimal dose of an investigational product.
A type of study designed to evaluate the relationship between dose and resulting exposure.
A study of the effect of dose changes on the efficacy of a drug in order to determine the dose-response relationship and optimal dose of a therapy.
A type of study designed to evaluate the interaction between drugs, where the use of one may affect the disposition, efficacy, or safety of the other.
A study that evaluates the effect of a treatment on cardiac electrical activity, as assessed by electrocardiography.
A study of the relative therapeutic efficacy of treatment of a disease. Usually this is a Phase II or III study. (NCI)
Studies that are conducted to assess the effect of food on the rate and extent of absorption of a drug, either compared to a fasted state or to a reference drug.
A study that assesses an agent's ability to provoke an immune response.
A type of study designed to evaluate the overall pathways of metabolism and excretion of a drug, and to identify and/or quantify metabolites in plasma and excreta.
A study of the biochemical and physiological effect of a drug and the mechanism of drug action and the relationship between drug concentration and effect. (NCI)

A study that assesses the value associated with a given drug in therapeutic and economic terms. This type of study is multidisciplinary in nature and takes into consideration the social and economic costs (resource utilization costs including direct, indirect, and intangible costs) of drug therapy in addition to its direct therapeutic benefits. Analyses relate the difference in therapeutic benefits to the difference in costs between treatment alternatives. (NCI)
A study that assesses variation in DNA sequence, usually within a single gene, and its effect on drug response.
A study that identifies or assesses variations within the entire genome, including DNA, RNA, or transcriptional elements, and its effects on drug response.
A study of the process by which a drug is absorbed, distributed, metabolized, and eliminated by the body. (NCI)
A type of study designed to evaluate the effect of body position during and/or after administration of the investigational product.
A type of study designed to identify actions necessary to permanently eliminate or reduce the long-term risk to human life as a result of a particular medication or treatment regimen.
A type of study designed to evaluate the expected, acute types of immunological responses, sometimes considered excessive, following agent administration.

A study that assesses the medical risks to a subject. Safety is usually assessed by examining a wide range of clinical parameters, including adverse events, vital signs, physical exam, laboratory tests.
A type of study designed to evaluate the effect of the investigational product on the physiologic act of swallowing.

A type of study designed to evaluate the ability of an investigational product and/or approved drug to delay cardiac ventricular repolarization as detected by QT prolongation and other ECG parameters.
A type of safety study that assesses the degree to which overt adverse effects can be tolerated by the subject.
A type of study designed to evaluate intervention(s) for treatment of disease, syndrome or condition.
A type of study designed to evaluate the user experience with a product.
A type of study designed to evaluate the effects of water on investigational product safety and/or efficacy.
